Award.AwardTitle: Collaboratice Research: Stable isotope tracers of the subsurface biosphere and its geochemical effects in oceanic ridge flank basement
Award.AbstractNarration: A vast subsurface biosphere exists beneath the seafloor, but there is little understanding of exactly how microbes affect chemical exchange between seawater and oceanic basement, or how this affects global geochemical budgets. Recent research shows that microbes have an active role in altering the volcanic rocks on the seafloor, and new isotope techniques have been developed that can tell the temperatures at which the alteration has taken place. This research uses the stable isotopes of sulfur and oxygen in altered seafloor mafic lavas sampled by NSF-funded Ocean Drilling Program to (1) trace the distribution of the subsurface biosphere in the oceanic basement, (2) understand how microbial processes affect chemical and isotope exchange between seawater and the crust, and (3) determine the influence of microbial processes on geochemical cycling in the oceans. This is the first study of its kind, and as such is potentially transformative in terms of its ability to inform us about life in the deep biosphere. Research will involve the sulfur contents and isotopes in rocks from cool fluid downwelling sites along the flanks of mid-ocean ridges. The oxygen isotope compositions of phosphate adsorbed to iron-oxyhydroxides from warm and cool sites will also be analyzed to examine the effects of in-situ biological activity and estimate the temperature at which microbial metabolic processes are occurring, giving an idea of the depth in the ocean crust to which life extends. The broader impacts of the work include support of an African American female researcher and the training of undergraduates and a postdoc in state-of-the-art stable isotope techniques. Minority high school students in the New Haven CT area will also be engaged in the laboratory research. In addition, public outreach associated with the project will be carried out by the Peabody Museum in New Haven and the University of Michigan Nano-Rocks summer high school camp. The work will incorporate research results into courses and support analytical facilities at both institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Where there is life, there is phosphorus (P) and in Earth environments P is present primarily in the form of phosphate (PO4). It has been demonstrated through several previous studies in our grour that ratio  of oxygen isotopes (18O/16O) in PO4 dissolved in natural waters an found in sediments/soils, carries a signature of specific  types of biological (enzymatic) activity and also records temperature. The goal of the proposed research was to analyze the 18O/16O ratios  of phosphate adsorbed onto Fe oxyhydroxides in altered basalts from warm and cold flank sites, in order to A) test the hypothesis that the O isotope composition of phosphate adsorbed onto Fe-oxyhydroxides in altered basalts records the effects of (in situ) biological activity; B) estimate temperatures of biological activity and P uptake; and C) further understand controls on P uptake by ocean crust and its role in the oceanic budget of P. In In addition to chemical and isotopic analyses we used high-resolution imaging and analyses including:  nanoSIMS and focused ion beam (FIB) SEM and FIB-assisted tomographic imaging; Diffuse reflectance Infra-red Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS) and microRaman spectrometry to investigate the occurrence of PO4 , detailed internal structures/porosity of microbial Fe-oxide stalks and retention of PO4biosignatures within  microbially-produced iron oxides from pure cultures and from cored mat samples

Key outcomes:

•Significant advances in our understanding of association of PO4 with microbial iron oxide structures and the internal porosity and elemental associations (e.g., C, P) within microbial iron oxides 

•Evidence showing abilitiy of Maryprofundus ferrooxydans to create biosignatures in PO4 associated with the iron oxides produced by and near these microbes whcih are key iron mat forming organisms in marine hydrothermal environments

•Direct measurements of the d18O value of PO4 in intact organic biomolecules and intact soft tissue biomass and confirmation of the  hypothesis that this PO4  also records temperature and biological activity similar to hard phosphatic tissues such as teeth/bones/scales/shells

•4 peer-reviewed papers and 10 conference presentations

This project also provided research opportunities and mentoring leading to an MS degree,  and to the successful transistion of 3 female postdocs into academic and government research laboratory positions as well as  one male postdoc's trasition into a tenure-track position. Research also supported development of one female PhD student now in her final year.
